title: Introduction
body:
Fears over collecting, using and sharing personal data often results in data not getting to those who need it. The challenge starts with understanding just what personal data is, the difference between this and sensitive commercial data, and the role of data protection regulations, which many see as a blocker to collecting, using and sharing personal data. 

The aim of this module is to increase understanding of personal data and techniques that can be applied to ensure the rights of individuals are protected, while maximising the the utility of data.

title: Topics
body:
This module introduces:

  • the differences between personal, sensitive personal, and sensitive commercial data
  • the importance of understanding who owns personal data
  • the rights of individuals over personal data
  • the role of data protection regulations
  • establishing a lawful basis for the ethical collection, use and sharing of (personal) data
  • techniques to reduce the risks of handling personal data.

title: Classifying personal and sensitive data
instruction: Select your answer from the drop downs. When done click 'Submit'

_items.text: A person's name
A person's religion
A shop's income
The location of a weather station

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

As an easy to remember rule, any data or information directly relating to an identifiable individual is personal, including pictures of a person, or group of people. 

Sensitive personal data is that which requires extra protection due to its nature, for example genetic data, health records or data that can potentially be used to discriminate, such as religion, sexual orientation and race.

Any data not relating to a person, such as the income of a business or the locations of things, is not personal, but it may be deemed commercially sensitive.

title: Defining personal, sensitive personal and sensitive commercial data
body:
Personal data: Information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person.

Sensitive personal data: Personal data that requires extra protection due to its nature, for example genetic data, health records or data that can potentially be used to discriminate.

Sensitive commercial data: Non-personal data, such as the income of a business or the locations of things. It is often deemed sensitive as the use and sharing of data may still result in harmful impacts.

Be aware: Different countries may also have their own definitions and categories for personal and sensitive personal data, defined by data protection regulations. The data protection regulations of the UK and Europe are used as reference for content presented here.

title: Who owns personal data?
body: Can you correctly identify the owner of the following?
instruction: Select your answers from the drop downs. When done click 'Submit'

_items.text: A tweet you write
Your Facebook profile picture
A survey conducted by a company you contribute you

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Providing there is, or has been, an intellectual effort in creating something, the person who put in the effort is the owner of the thing created.

The tweets you write, photographs you take, spreadsheets you create; these are all owned by you.

In a case where you interact with a survey, platform or service, the owner of the data created as a result of your interaction will be the company, for example the research institute or the social media platform. This is because the intellectual effort in the creation of the survey or service came from the provider, you are simply interacting with it.

title: The importance of understanding who owns personal data
body:
Not all data about you is your data. In fact you own very little of the data about you. But because personal data is about you, you have rights over it, and this is why we have data protection regulations: to protect the rights of individuals.

Around the world many countries have been updating data protection regulations to account for people now interacting online. In an increasingly frictionless data world, clear guidance needs to be in place not just on what individuals’ rights to personal data, but also the lawful basis for using, storing and retaining personal data, both within a country and internationally.

Data protection regulations are not there to prevent data reaching those who need it. They are there to protect the privacy and rights of the people the data is about.

title: The rights of individuals over personal data

_items.title: Right to be informed
_items.body: Individuals have the right to be informed about how personal data about them is collected and used. This information should be presented in a ‘privacy notice’. This should be presented to the individual when data is collected, in clear, concise language, and in a way that is easily accessible.

_items.title: Right to access (subject access requests)
_items.body: The right to access gives people the right to request a copy of the personal information an individual or organisation (the data controller) holds about them. There are exceptions to this, such as when that personal information is being used for criminal proceedings or sensitive legal obligations.

_items.title: Right to rectification
_items.body: Individuals have the right to have personal data corrected if it is inaccurate or incomplete. The data controller also has responsibilities to ensure the data is corrected if it is shared with others.

_items.title: Right to be forgotten
_items.body: The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles an individual to direct the data controller to erase personal data about them, cease further sharing of the data, and, potentially, halt processing of the data by third parties.

_items.title: Right to restrict processing
_items.body:
Individuals have a right to ‘block’ or suppress processing of personal data. 

Such rights can be exercised when:

  • the accuracy of the personal data is contested
  • where the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest)
  • the processing is unlawful
  • the data is needed for future reference but should no longer be processed.

_items.title: Right to data portability
_items.body: Individuals can request that personal data about them be transferred directly to another controller. To this point, we have only seen the financial sector adopt the right to data portability as a way to build better banking services. The global open banking initiative allows customers to directly transfer personal data between financial service providers, meaning you can change banks without having to fill in endless forms.

_items.title: Right to object or withdraw consent
_items.body: If the lawful basis for processing data is based on having consent, the individual has the right to withdraw that consent at any time. The process of withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving consent in the first place. If a different lawful basis other than consent is being used as the basis for processing personal data, individuals may have the right to object to that processing.

_items.title: Right to not be subject solely to automated decision making
_items.body: Individuals have the right to not be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling. In all cases individuals must be informed about the automated processing and be able to request human intervention or challenge a decision.

title: The role of data protection regulations
body:
Generally, data protection regulations set out the following: 

  1. Definitions of personal and sensitive personal data
  2. Geographic restrictions relating specifically to personal data
  3. The lawful basis under which personal data can be processed
  4. The rights of individuals over personal data about them
  5. The responsibilities of data controllers in relation to personal data

title: The role of data protection regulations
body:
Different countries have their own data protection legislation, which enable personal data to be used while protecting the rights of individuals. The most important thing to remember is that personal data cannot be collected or processed without a lawful basis; if no lawful basis applies then it is illegal to hold the personal data.

A lawful basis is often detailed as part of the data governance and privacy impact assessments made by an organisation, and should also be clear to individuals as part of the organisation’s privacy notice.

Once the lawful basis is established, all other aspects, such as rights of individuals, will be matched to this.

title: Techniques to reduce the risks of handling personal data
body: What steps can be taken to reduce the risks of handling personal data?

_items.text: Avoid the problem by not collecting personal data in the first place
Anonymise the data, removing any personal information
Delete the personal information, or create a synthetic dataset of fictional people
Don’t tell anyone you that you have personal data
Store the data in a country with weaker data protection regulations

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Personal data should only be collected and stored if it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis. If you don’t need it, don’t collect it. The same applies to retaining personal data. 

As an alternative to deleting data, anonymisation techniques could be applied that remove any personal data that can identify a specific individual. 

Alternatively you could consider creating a synthetic dataset. A synthetic dataset contains many of the statistical patterns of an original dataset, but does not refer to identifiable individuals (for example it contains fictional people), thereby reducing the risk of re-identification.

Trying to hide the data – or storing it in a different country –  are not solutions as data protection laws apply where an organisation has its principal place of business, regardless of where the data is stored.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Personal data should only be collected and stored if it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis. If you don’t need it, don’t collect it. The same applies to retaining personal data. 

As an alternative to deleting data, anonymisation techniques could be applied that remove any personal data that can identify a specific individual. 

Alternatively you could consider creating a synthetic dataset. A synthetic dataset contains many of the statistical patterns of an original dataset, but does not refer to identifiable individuals (for example it contains fictional people), thereby reducing the risk of re-identification.

Trying to hide the data – or storing it in a different country –  are not solutions as data protection laws apply where an organisation has its principal place of business, regardless of where the data is stored.

title: Data protection and anonymised/synthetic data
body: Do data protection regulations apply to anonymised or synthetic data?

_items.text: Yes
No

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Once the data is anonymised, data protection regulations no longer apply and data can be shared with others safely, even outside the geographical boundaries that may be imposed by data protection regulations.

However, this does not mean that the retention, use and sharing (or not sharing) of the data will be ethical, even if it is legal.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

title: Summary
body:
Concerns over collecting, using and sharing personal data often results in data not getting to those who need it. The challenge starts with understanding just what personal data is, the difference between this and sensitive commercial data, and the role of data protection regulations, which many see as a blocker to sharing personal data.

Increasing understanding of personal data, data protection regulations and techniques that can be applied to anonymise data all help minimise the risks of handling personal data. This is essential to ensure the rights of individuals are protected.

title: The rights of individuals over personal data
body:
Regardless of how data is collected or processed, individuals have the right to be informed about how data about them is processed and for what purpose. Further, this must be specific. ‘Privacy notices’ stating that personal data is used to ‘improve the level of service’ are no longer valid under modern data protection regulations, as they are not specific.

Additionally the following rights are emerging globally, both within data protection regulations and also as best practice, even when relating to non-personal data.

title: Knowing your rights
body: Under modern data protection regulations, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), what rights do individuals have over data about them?

_items.text: The right to be informed how data about them is processed
The right to access data about them
The right to object or withdraw consent
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Regardless of how data is collected or processed, individuals have the right to be informed about how data about them is processed, and for what purpose. 

In many situations, especially where consent is used as a lawful basis for processing personal data, individuals also have the right to access, rectify or even object to data about them being stored and processed.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Regardless of how data is collected or processed, individuals have the right to be informed about how data about them is processed, and for what purpose.

title: Establishing a lawful basis for the ethical collection, use and sharing of (personal) data
body: Can you establish the lawful basis for the following:
instruction: Select your answers from the drop downs. When done click 'submit'

_items.text: Sharing data on vulnerable people with supermarkets to prioritise home delivery of food and essential supplies to those shielding from a pandemic.
Checking a person's age before allowing them to purchase alcohol or other age-restricted goods.
Collecting personal information to enrol someone on a certified educational programme.
Using the personal details collected above to send future marketing for other educational programmes.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Not everything needs a person’s consent. The provision of many services is covered under the performance of contract with the consumer or legal obligations (or public duties) with which the provider has to abide.

Deciding if vital or legitimate interest applies relies on being proportionate – if something feels excessive from the public’s point of view, then it probably is. The Information Commissioner's Office in the UK provides some excellent guidance on this. 

Considering carefully the ethics of your reasons for collecting, using and sharing (or not sharing) the data will help you decide if such a basis can apply. 

Regardless of the lawful basis, it is always a good idea to keep people informed about how data will be collected, used and shared, be that via a privacy notice (if using personal information) or via other means.

Note on question 1: Although vital interest is usually used as the basis for sharing data during times of crisis, sometimes legitimate interest is equally valid. Either way, it was deemed in the interests of those in the UK who were instructed to shield at home that permitted the NHS to share data with supermarkets so food delivery could be prioritised. Obviously this doesn’t mean supermarkets can retain the data following the shielding programme ending, and have been warned they will have no lawful basis for doing so.

title: Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
displayTitle: Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
body:
Data protection regulations require everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. There are six lawful bases outlined in UK data protection regulations (adopted from the EU GDPR). At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if the same task could be reasonably performed without collecting personal data then the lawful basis does not apply. 

Relying on consent gives individuals the data is about the widest selection of rights, so this should be considered carefully before simply adopting it.
instruction: Explore the six lawful basis in the sections below:

_items.title: Public task
_items.body:
Personal data can be processed where it is necessary to perform a task in the public interest or for official functions, where the task or function has a clear basis in law.

Examples include provision or public utilities, e.g. water, electricity and education. 

When it doesn’t apply: To create an Alumni network of University leavers or for fundraising.

_items.title: Performance of contract
_items.body:
Personal data can be processed when there is a need to fulfil a contract with an individual, or if the individual has asked for specific steps to be taken before entering into a contract.

For example, personal data can be processed to provide a quote for fitting double glazing on a house and the subsequent fitting. It can also be processed in order to assess the financial position of someone prior to purchasing large items such as a car or house.

_items.title: Legal obligation
_items.body:
Under this basis, personal data can be processed in order to comply with UK law. For example, to comply with UK employment law. Contractual obligations with third parties do not count as a legal basis for processing. 

When using this basis, the individual has no right to data portability, or right to object. An individual has a right to erasure if the legal obligation has expired. For example, if someone left a company over 3 years ago then there is unlikely to be a legal obligation for the employer to keep hold of data about that person (a very small quantity is required for longer).

_items.title: Vital interests
_items.body:
Under this basis, personal data can be processed if it is necessary to protect someone’s life. This does not apply if the person’s vital interests can be protected in another less intrusive way.

This lawful basis also does not apply for health data or other special category data if the individual is capable of giving consent.

A common example of vital interests is in crisis response situations, such as natural disasters/emergencies, outbreak of an epidemic/pandemic etc.

_items.title: Legitimate interests
_items.body:
Under this basis personal data can be processed if it is in the legitimate interests of the individual, third parties, or society. Legitimate interests is the most flexible lawful basis for processing, but it cannot be assumed it will always be the most appropriate.

For a legitimate interest to apply, a data controller/processors interests must be balanced against the individual’s. If an individual would not reasonably expect the processing, or if it would cause unjustified harm, their interests are likely to override those of the controller/processor.

_items.title: Informed consent
_items.body:
To use this basis, individuals must be informed about how personal data is going to be used and consent given for each individual use. Consent cannot ask for open-ended permission to use data however the controller wants, such as “to improve our service”. 

Gaining consent must be through clear affirmative action, such as a button press or an opt-in tick box. Hidden conditions and opt-out options where no action is required does not constitute clearly obtained consent under UK Data Protection regulations and GDPR. 

Additionally the individual must be able to withdraw their consent at any time. The process for withdrawing consent must be as easy to complete as that for giving consent.

title: Synthetic data
body: A synthetic dataset contains many of the statistical patterns of an original dataset, but does not refer to identifiable individuals (for example it contains fictional people), thereby reducing the risk of re-identification. Intuitively, it is easy to see how this could enable the sharing or open release of data similar to very sensitive data, but with less risk of data protection infringement attached to it.
instruction: Explore some case studies in synthetic data:

_items.title: Synthetic data and digital twins
_items.body: One problem that can arise with AI system is a lack of training data. For example, to train an AI to recognise defects from images of objects; it is first necessary to have images of defective objects. Rather than gather real world images, one potential is to use a digital twin of the object to create a synthetic dataset of objects with defects (ie. using CAD software). This can then form 90% of the training data with real work data used to test accuracy. Additionally the dataset can be created under controlled conditions, minimising a number of biases and speeding up collection.

_items.title: Diagnosing the NHS: SynÆ
_items.body:
NHS England recognise that data is useful. Summary data about A&E departments of UK hospitals are big news. Waiting times data is analysed and fills front pages, the TV, and the radio. Things get political very quickly.

But an average waiting time doesnt tell us much about what's really happening.

Who needed care? At what time? For what problem? And what happened as a result?

Detailed A&E admissions data is far too sensitive to be made open. It is rightly afforded special category status within both the GDPR and The Data Protection Act 2018.

Synthetic data provides a potential method through which statistically accurate data can be shared. 

You can read more about the work of ODI Leeds and NHS England on creating synthentic A&E data here including detail on the methodology.
